etymology.description: ideogrammic compound: lid 冖 + mouth 口 + stand 士 (vessel on a stand).
etymology.interpretation: Builds up the image of a lidded container: the cover and mouth of the pot are shown, resting on a base. The combined elements point to the function and shape of a pot or jar rather than supplying a phonetic cue.
etymology.simplification: The traditional 壺 was streamlined to 壶 by pruning interior strokes and compressing the vessel depiction into a simpler form while keeping the overall silhouette, reducing stroke count for easier writing.

examples.chinese: 我把茶倒进壶(我把茶倒進壺)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bǎ chá dào jìn hú.
examples.english: I pour the tea into the pot.

examples.chinese: 这个壶很古老(這個壺很古老)。
他买了一个紫砂壶(他買了一個紫砂壺)。
examples.pinyin: Tā mǎi le yí gè zǐshā hú.
examples.english: He bought a Yixing clay teapot.
